result.execSummary:
The defendant was charged with both OWI (2nd) and Operating w/ PAC (2nd). The defendant was found guilty of OWI (2nd) and the other charge, Operating w/ PAC (2nd) was dismissed by the court.

  • Brian L Pearlman was found guilty of Vehicle Operator Flee/Elude Officer, a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.04(3).
  • Brian L Pearlman was found guilty of OWI (2nd), an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Probation may be transferred to Kenosha County. Will consider early termination of Probation after 30 months is completed and approved by Agent.

miscConds.notes: BAIL APPLIED. COSTS AND DNA PAID IN FULL
Maintain full time employment and/or school.
Submit to an AODA Assessment and follow through with any treatment/counseling recommended.

Maintain absolute sobriety.
Submit to random alcohol/drug screens.
Not to use or possess of alcohol or controlled substances without a valid prescription or any drug paraphernalia.
Any valid prescription drugs must be taken only in the manner in which they are prescribed.
Inform Agent of all prescriptions.
Follow through with any treatment/counseling recommended.
Not to operate a MV without a valid license.
No contact with Tamara B. 
Defendant to provide DNA sample, if not yet provided,   immediately if in custody otherwise within (3) business days at the Waukesha County Sheriff Department.
Count 3 was dismissed outright.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Brian L Pearlman

records.addlTxt: From defendant dated 4/13/18 re case.

Notice of Case Status Change - Defendant was Discharged from Probation/Extended Supervision - Early
  Outstanding financial obligations have been satisfied.
Return of Order on Petition for Early Discharge from Probation.
Order on Early Termination of Probation signed by Judge Aprahamian.

Defendant Brian L Pearlman in court by telephone with attorney Mark P. Powers.   District Attorney's Office Law Intern appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  The court calls the case to address the letter recommending early termination filed by the Tennessee Department of of Corrections.  The state objects to the request.  Attorney Powers requests the court terminate probation early.  The court grants early termination of probation after 30 months on 4/5/18.   The court to prepare an order.
Notice of Hearing returned, for hearing scheduled on: 2/23/18
Review hearing on February 23, 2018 at 08:30 am.

From Agent dated 1/25/18 in support of early release from probation.
Reviewed by Judge Aprahamian 1/29/18 - Agent and Defendant can appear by phone.

records.addlTxt: Wisconsin Community Service compliance letter received and filed.

Defendant Brian L Pearlman in court with attorney Mark P. Powers.  Andrea M. Will appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Parties proceed to sentencing on Cts. 1 and 2.  

Court orders the following: 
Ct. 1:
- Total sentence: 2 years 2 months  (Initial Confinement: 13 months, Extended Supervision: 13 months)  Stayed for 3 years Probation - maybe transferred to Kenosha. Ct. 1 consecutive to Ct. 2. Court will consider early
termination of probation after 30 months is completed and approved by the Agent. 
- Court Costs of $268.00 - apply bail
- DNA Surcharge of $250.00 - apply bail      
- Conditions of  Probation: AODA assessment and follow through with any treatment/counseling. Maintain absolute sobriety. Random U.A.'s..   Follow thru with any treatment/counseling recommended by Agent. No use or possession of alcohol or controlled substances without a valid prescription. No drug paraphernalia. Any valid prescription drugs must be taken only in the manner in which they are prescribed; Inform Agent of all prescriptions. Maintain full-time employment and/or combination of schooling. No operate a motor vehicle without a valid DL. No contact with Tamara B..   Defendant to provide DNA sample, if not yet provided, immediately if in custody otherwise within (3) business days at the Waukesha County Sheriff Department. 
 - Defendant to perform 75 hours of community service as a condition of Probation.
 - 30 days jail Condition Time (nonworking hours)   STAYED to be used at the Agents discretion. Huber/Straight time to be used at the Agents discretion. 

Ct.  2:
-  180 days jail with Huber to commence on October 5, 2015 by 6:00 p.m.. Huber with standard release conditions. 20 days Credit.  Sentence maybe transferred to Kenosha County. 
-    18 months Drivers License Revocation. 
-    18 months Ignition Interlock every vehicle TITLED OR REGISTERED to defendant
- Attendance at the Victim Impact Panel meeting on November 18, 2015 or 20 days jail with Huber consecutive.
- Alcohol Assessment 
- Blood Test Reimbursement of $35.00 paid through Waukesha County Circuit Court to be forwarded toWaukesha Memorial Hospital - apply bail 
- Fine totaling $1179.00 - apply bail

with Elements of criminal offenses to which plea is being entered.

Defendant Brian L Pearlman in court with attorney Mark P. Powers.  Timothy Suha appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant enters a plea of no contest to Count 1.  Court finds defendant guilty.   Defendant enters a guilty plea to Count 2.  Court finds defendant guilty. Ct. 3 dismissed by operation of law. Defense requests another date for sentencing. Court grants request.

Preliminary hearing on February 19, 2015 at 08:15 am.

Absolute sobriety, defendant is not to possess or consume any alcohol.  Defendant is not to use/possess any controlled substances without a valid prescription and take as prescribed. Defendant is not to operate a motor vehicle unless properly licensed.  Defendant to report/comply with Wisconsin Community Services (WCS) Intoxicated Driver Program and must report within 1 business day following release.  Defendant to have no contact with any victim/witness listed in the Criminal Complaint. Court allows the defendant to travel out of State to attend the program at the Oxford Center. WCS can be done by telephone as to the monitoring of the defendant while he is at the Center.
